Straight hair developed because people with straight hair can soak up more sun than people with curly afro or curly hair, straight hair holds less moisture and helps keep heat.
Imagine, how straight hair would be beneficial in cold climates where you need the least moisture possible on your head, need hair to keep you warm and there's a lack of sun so you need hair with less volume to get that vitamin D.
People with afros , curled hair and dark skin developed riquets which would be a deadly disease in hunter gatherer societies and warring kingdoms.
Now, there's a disadvantage to having afro hair and dark skin in northern climates but there isn't a disadvantage to having light skin and straight hair in hot climates.
Those humans that went northward and developed those characteristics eventually moved southward and din't lose any of their characteristic straight hair or light skin.
That's because sun exposure only leads to cancer waaaaayy after the reproductive years and straight hair isn't really disadvantagious.

The reason why most Africans have curly hair is to defend themselves against UV rays while reducing conducting heat. When you have hair that twist in a spiral, you cover a larger surface area without the addition of more follicles. It doesn't make sense to have more follicles in a warmer environment. This is why those with blonde hair have more hair per square inch. This generates more heat. Great designs for both humans adapted for the heat and the cold.

Okay, I have a goofy question for you people -- is it a common thing that humans consider predatory animals (land-based anyway, because sharks seem to freak us out) to be extremely attractive, and if so -- WHY? If we evolved from small mammals, shouldn't we have inherited some genetic tendency to find even animals like cats and birds of prey horrifying?

And on the flip side, is it common for humans to be totally grossed out by bugs? It sure seems like an inherent quality for us to be completely horrified by insects and arachnids in some limbic-system way, but then to be horrified by tiny spiders and turned into sentimental goo by tigers makes no damned sense.

So how common is it for humans to be either sentimental or horrified by certain classes of animals, and if it is common, what the hell could possibly be the reason why we'd would consider predators to be beautiful? I hypothesize that the neurons of some people can also display a sort of curliness in their developmental stage when there are links being made to other neurons. This would determine how wide/large of an area they might develop interneural connections in. Perhaps people with neurons that are more linked further apart in space have more abstract/creative thoughts than people with more closely knit neural connections. Myelin sheaths might also be related to allow for nerves to extend further. Possibly also related to why Einstein's brain had more cross hemispherical connections than average.....On that note, I wonder if something analogous to a Brachistochrone curve applies to neuron pathways.
